note_text:
Indication: LUL 1.9cm SCC. Protocol PULSE-LUNG.
Anesthesia: GA.
Procedure: ENB to LUL apicoposterior. rEBUS confirmed. PFA catheter placement. 3 cycles 1500V.
Findings: Increased echogenicity post-ablation. No thermal damage.
Complications: None.
Plan: Protocol follow-up.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text: OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: Ms. Williams, a 58-year-old female enrolled in the PULSE-LUNG Phase II trial, underwent bronchoscopic Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) for a biopsy-proven squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe. Under general anesthesia, the lesion was localized via electromagnetic navigation and radial EBUS. The investigational FarapulsePulm catheter was deployed. Irreversible electroporation was delivered in three cycles of 1500V pulses. Post-ablation imaging demonstrated cellular disruption consistent with successful non-thermal ablation. The patient tolerated the procedure without arrhythmia or hemodynamic instability.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text:
CPT Coding: 31641 (Bronchoscopic destruction of tumor - Investigational PFA).
Guidance: 31627 (ENB), 31654 (Radial EBUS).
Device: FarapulsePulm PFA catheter.
Details: Non-thermal energy, 1500V, 3 cycles.
Target: LUL Peripheral Nodule.
Status: Clinical Trial (IDE #BR-PFA-2024-017).

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text:
Procedure Note
Attending: Dr. Patel
Patient: Janet Williams
Procedure: PFA of LUL nodule
Steps:
1. GA/ETT.
2. Navigated to LUL apicoposterior segment.
3. Confirmed with rEBUS.
4. Inserted PFA catheter.
5. Delivered 3 cycles of pulsed energy (1500V).
6. Monitored impedance - good delivery.
7. Extubated stable.
Note: No arrhythmias observed.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text: janet williams here for the research study pulsed field ablation. she has squamous cell in the lul. we put her to sleep used the nav system to find the spot. put the special catheter in and zapped it 3 times with the electric pulses. no heat damage which is good. heart rhythm stayed fine. patient woke up ok going to follow the study protocol for scans.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text:
[Indication]
LUL SCC, 1.9cm. PULSE-LUNG Trial candidate.
[Anesthesia]
General Anesthesia.
[Description]
ENB and rEBUS localization. PFA delivered (1500V x 3 cycles). Non-thermal ablation confirmed via rEBUS changes.
[Plan]
CT at 48 hours. Long-term registry.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text: Ms. Williams participated in our PFA clinical trial today to treat her left upper lobe tumor. We used electromagnetic navigation to guide the specialized catheter to the site. Instead of heat, we used high-voltage electrical pulses to destroy the tumor cells. The procedure went perfectly according to protocol, and we saw immediate signs on the ultrasound that the tissue was treated. Her heart rhythm remained stable throughout.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text: Subject: Williams, Janet S. Procedure: Bronchoscopic Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA). Methodology: General anesthesia. ENB performed. Target: LUL apicoposterior segment. Radial EBUS verification. Novel PFA catheter advanced. Ablation Parameters: Voltage 1500 V. Energy delivery: Non-thermal. Outcomes: Successfully completed per protocol. No arrhythmias observed. Disposition: Research protocol follow-up.

notes: Investigational Pulsed Field Ablation (PFA) of peripheral nodule.
31641 (Tumor destruction) used as proxy for ablation.

note_text:
Indication: RML collapse.
Findings: Exophytic tumor obstructing RML.
Action: Forceps biopsy x6. Wash.
Comp: Moderate bleeding, controlled with epi/iced saline.
Impression: Endobronchial tumor.

PROCEDURE REPORT: Ms. Chen presented for evaluation of right middle lobe collapse. Bronchoscopy revealed a near-complete obstruction of the RML bronchus by a necrotic, exophytic mass. Diagnostic sampling was performed via forceps biopsy and bronchial lavage. Hemostasis was achieved using topical vasoconstrictors after moderate hemorrhage was encountered.

Code: 31625 (Bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsy).
Site: Right Middle Lobe Bronchus.
Pathology: Exophytic tumor.
Sampling: 6 forceps biopsies.
Note: Bronchial wash (31622) performed but bundled. 31623 (Brush) not performed.

Resident Note
Patient: Elizabeth Chen
Procedure: Bronchoscopy
- Local anesthesia.
- Airway: RML obstructed by tumor.
- Biopsy: 6 bites taken from RML mass.
- Bleeding: Moderate, stopped with epi.
- Lavage collected.
- Patient stable.

patient elizabeth chen date of birth 1962. indication rml collapse. topical lidocaine used patient awake. rml is blocked by a tumor looks necrotic. took about 6 biopsies bleeding was moderate so we used epinephrine and cold saline. rll and left side looked normal. lavage sent for cytology. tolerated well.

[START RECORDING 14:32] Patient name is Elizabeth Chen, medical record Papa Lima dash four eight two nine dash Quebec, date of birth November twenty-third nineteen sixty-two. [14:33] Indication is evaluation of right middle lobe collapse with concern for endobronchial obstruction. [14:34] Topical anesthesia achieved with nebulized lidocaine four percent followed by transtracheal injection of two percent lidocaine... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
RML collapse, rule out obstruction.
[Anesthesia]
Topical Lidocaine.
[Description]
RML obstructed by exophytic tumor. Biopsy x6 and Lavage performed. Bleeding controlled.
[Plan]
Pathology pending.

We examined Ms. Chen's airways to investigate why her right middle lung was collapsed. We found a tumor blocking the airway to that section. We took six biopsy samples from the mass. There was some bleeding, which is common with these tumors, but we stopped it with medication. We also washed the area to collect cells for analysis.

Patient name is Elizabeth Chen. Indication is evaluation of right middle lobe collapse. Right middle lobe bronchus displays near complete obstruction by an exophytic tumor. Multiple forceps biopsies acquired from the tumor. Moderate hemorrhage encountered, controlled with topical epinephrine. Bronchial lavage acquired from RML. Patient tolerated well.

Emergency Bronchoscopy.
Indication: Central airway obstruction (RML).
Event: Massive hemoptysis (300mL) during debulking.
Action: Hemostasis (blocker/epi). Stent placed (14x40mm).
Dispo: ICU, intubated.

OPERATIVE SUMMARY: Ms. Kim underwent therapeutic bronchoscopy for RML tumor debulking. The procedure was complicated by massive hemoptysis estimated at 300mL. Hemodynamic stability was maintained while hemostasis was achieved using a bronchial blocker and iced saline. A 14x40mm silicone stent was deployed to secure the airway and tamponade the bleeding vessel. The patient was transferred to the MICU intubated for monitoring.

Codes: 31641 (Tumor destruction), 31636 (Stent placement - bronchial).
Context: Complex therapeutic bronchoscopy.
Complication: Severe hemorrhage requiring tamponade.
Device: Silicone stent 14x40mm.
Disposition: Critical care.

Resident Note
Patient: Barbara Kim
Procedure: Therapeutic Bronchoscopy
- RML tumor debulking started.
- Massive bleeding occurred.
- Blocked RML, used epi/ice.
- Placed silicone stent.
- Bleeding stopped.
- Patient remains intubated in ICU.

barbara kim 69 female therapeutic bronch for rml obstruction. started debulking with apc and cautery then massive bleeding started like 300ml. scary moment. put a blocker in and used ice. put a stent in 14 by 40 silicone. bleeding stopped. keep her asleep in the icu check blood counts.

Pt: Barbara Kim | MR: PP-8473 | DOB: 06/30/1955 | AGE: 69 PROCEDURE: Therapeutic bronchoscopy - central airway obstruction AIRWAY: General anesthesia, ETT 7.5, maintained throughout INTERVENTION PERFORMED: - RML tumor debulking (electrocautery + APC) - Massive hemoptysis during procedure (est. 300mL) - Controlled with: epi, iced saline, blocker in RML - Silicone stent 14x40mm placed... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
RML Tumor Obstruction.
[Anesthesia]
General, ETT.
[Description]
Debulking initiated. Complicated by massive hemoptysis. Hemostasis achieved. Silicone stent placed (14x40mm).
[Plan]
MICU admission. Mechanical ventilation.

Ms. Kim's procedure was intended to clear a tumor blocking her right middle airway. During the removal process, she experienced severe bleeding. We acted quickly to block the area and apply cold saline to stop the flow. We then placed a silicone stent to keep the airway open and put pressure on the bleeding site. She is currently stable but remains on a ventilator in the ICU for close watching.

Pt: Barbara Kim. PROCEDURE: Therapeutic bronchoscopy. INTERVENTION EXECUTED: RML tumor debulking. Massive hemoptysis during procedure. Controlled with: epi, iced saline, blocker in RML. Silicone stent 14x40mm deployed. COMPLICATION: MAJOR AIRWAY HEMORRHAGE. CURRENT STATUS: Still intubated, sedated. TRANSFERRED TO: MICU.

Indication: 14mm LLL nodule.
Technique: ENB attempted. Failed to visualize lesion (no rEBUS signal).
Action: Aborted nav. Blind biopsy x3 and brush x1 performed.
Result: Nondiagnostic likely.
Plan: CT biopsy or VATS.

notes: Equipment used (Nav + REBUS) supports add-ons despite failure to confirm.

note_text: PROCEDURE NOTE: Ms. White underwent attempted electromagnetic navigation for a small LLL nodule. Despite extensive maneuvering and fluoroscopy (12.4 min), the radial EBUS probe failed to confirm a tool-in-lesion position. The navigation component was aborted. Blind transbronchial biopsies were obtained from the anatomical segment of interest. The patient was advised regarding the low likelihood of diagnostic yield.

notes: Equipment used (Nav + REBUS) supports add-ons despite failure to confirm.

note_text:
Codes: 31628 (Transbronchial biopsy), 31627 (Nav - attempted), 31654 (rEBUS - attempted).
Modifier: None (procedure performed, just unsuccessful localization).
Fluoro time: 12.4 min.
Outcome: Localization failed.

notes: Equipment used (Nav + REBUS) supports add-ons despite failure to confirm.

note_text: We tried to biopsy Ms. White's small lung nodule using the navigation system. Unfortunately, the anatomy was difficult, and we couldn't confirm the exact location with our ultrasound probe despite trying for 45 minutes. We took some samples from the general area, but we explained to her that we might not have hit the target. We may need to consider a needle biopsy or surgery next.

notes: Equipment used (Nav + REBUS) supports add-ons despite failure to confirm.

note_text: PATIENT: KAREN WHITE. INDICATION: LLL peripheral nodule. PROCEDURE ATTEMPTED: Electromagnetic navigation system configured. Navigation attempt: Guide sheath advanced. Radial EBUS probe deployed - NO concentric pattern visualized. Unable to verify tool-in-lesion. Decision: Procedure aborted due to inability to localize. Sampling performed anyway (blind): Forceps biopsies x3. Brush cytology x1.

notes: Equipment used (Nav + REBUS) supports add-ons despite failure to confirm.

note_text:
Indication: RLL nodule + Adenopathy.
EBUS: 4R(9mm) Pos, 7(11mm) Pos.
ENB: RLL 18mm nodule. rEBUS confirmed.
Sampling: TBNA x2, TBBx x3, Brush x2.
Result: N2 disease + Primary sampled.

OPERATIVE REPORT: Ms. Chen underwent combined staging and diagnostic bronchoscopy. EBUS-TBNA of stations 4R and 7 confirmed N2 nodal involvement (ROSE positive). Following this, electromagnetic navigation was used to localize an 18mm RLL lateral segment nodule. Tool-in-lesion was confirmed via radial EBUS. Transbronchial needle aspiration and forceps biopsies were obtained from the primary lesion.

Codes: 31652 (EBUS 2 stations), 31629 (Peripheral TBNA), 31654 (rEBUS), 31627 (Nav).
EBUS: 4R, 7.
Peripheral: RLL mass (TBNA, Forceps, Brush).
Diagnosis: Stage IIIB NSCLC.

Resident Note
Patient: Sarah Chen
Procedure: Staging EBUS + ENB
- Deep sedation.
- EBUS: Sampled 4R and 7. Both malignant.
- ENB: Navigated to RLL nodule.
- Confirmed with rEBUS.
- Took needle, forceps, and brush samples.
- Bleeding controlled.

sarah chen 67 female smoker rll mass and nodes. deep sedation propofol. did ebus first 4r and 7 both positive for cancer. then did navigation to the rll mass. radial ebus confirmed it. took 2 needle passes 3 biopsies and 2 brushes. moderate bleeding stopped with epi. discharged stable.

Name: Sarah Chen | MRN# PX-2947-B | Birth: 03/09/1965 Pre-procedure: 67yo former smoker with RLL peripheral nodule 18mm, no bronchus sign on CT. PET shows SUV 4.2. Anesthesia: Deep sedation - propofol infusion 75-100mcg/kg/min, Ramsay 4-5, BP q5min, SpO2 continuous Part 1 - EBUS staging for PET+ N2 nodes: Station 4R (9mm SA) - 4x passes, ROSE+, PET+ Station 7 (11mm SA) - 3x passes, ROSE+, PET+ Molecular testing sent from station 4R sample... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
RLL mass, mediastinal LAD.
[Anesthesia]
Deep Sedation.
[Description]
EBUS-TBNA of 4R and 7 (Both Positive). ENB to RLL mass. TBNA/TBBx/Brush performed. Bleeding controlled.
[Plan]
Chemoradiation.

We performed a two-part procedure for Ms. Chen. First, we used EBUS to check the lymph nodes in the center of her chest; stations 4R and 7 both showed cancer cells. Second, we used the navigation system to reach the main tumor in her right lower lung and took several biopsy samples. This confirms the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes (Stage IIIB), so we will discuss chemotherapy and radiation.

Name: Sarah Chen. Chief Indication: RUL mass with mediastinal LAD. Procedure Performed: 1. EBUS-TBNA for staging. 2. Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsy. EBUS Component: Systematic mediastinal evaluation. Station 4R: 5 passes, ROSE Positive. Station 7: 4 passes, ROSE Positive. Bronchoscopy Component: Examination revealed mass effect. Multiple forceps biopsies obtained. Assessment: N2/N3 disease verified.

Indication: 17mm LLL nodule.
Nav: ENB + rEBUS (concentric).
Samples: TBNA x3, TBBx x5, Brush x2.
Comp: Small apical PTX (15%). Stable.
Dispo: Discharge with follow-up CXR.

PROCEDURE NOTE: Mr. Lee underwent electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy for a 17mm LLL nodule. Localization was achieved after repositioning, confirmed by a concentric rEBUS view. Systematic sampling included TBNA, forceps biopsy, and brushing. Post-procedure radiography revealed a 15% apical pneumothorax. The patient remained asymptomatic with stable vitals. Conservative management was elected, and the patient was discharged with close radiographic follow-up.

Codes: 31629 (TBNA), 31654 (rEBUS), 31627 (Nav).
Biopsies: 3 needle, 5 forceps, 2 brush.
Adverse Event: Pneumothorax (J93.81) - Observation only.
Fluoro time: 7.2 min.

Resident Note
Patient: Martin Lee
Procedure: ENB
- Deep sedation.
- Navigated to LLL superior segment.
- rEBUS concentric.
- Samples: Needle, Forceps, Brush.
- Complication: Small pneumo on CXR.
- Patient stable, sent home.

case c-847 martin lee. enb for lll nodule 17mm. used superdimension system. had to reposition to get good ebus view but got it eventually. took needle biopsy forceps and brush. xray showed a small pneumothorax about 15 percent. he felt fine so we didnt put a tube in. sent him home will check xray tomorrow.

CASE PRESENTATION: Complex Navigation Bronchoscopy PATIENT DEMOGRAPHICS: A 64-year-old male (Case ID: C-847, Synthetic Name: Martin Lee, MRN: QQ-8473-R, DOB: 05/22/1960) former smoker with 45 pack-year history presented with an incidentally discovered left lower lobe peripheral pulmonary nodule. IMAGING CHARACTERISTICS: Computed tomography demonstrated a 17mm solid nodule in the left lower lobe superior segment without clear bronchus sign... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
LLL Nodule 17mm.
[Anesthesia]
Deep Sedation.
[Description]
ENB to LLL. rEBUS confirmed. TBNA x3, TBBx x5, Brush x2. Small PTX noted post-op.
[Plan]
Conservative management of PTX. Discharge.

Mr. Lee underwent a navigation bronchoscopy for a spot in his lower left lung. We successfully located the 17mm nodule using the electromagnetic system and confirmed it with ultrasound. We took multiple samples. Afterward, the chest x-ray showed a small lung collapse (pneumothorax). Since he had no symptoms and his oxygen levels were good, we decided he didn't need a chest tube and could go home with a follow-up x-ray scheduled.

CASE PRESENTATION: Complex Navigation Bronchoscopy. PROCEDURAL APPROACH: Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy was selected. Technical Details: The electromagnetic navigation system was employed. The extended working channel was advanced. Radial endobronchial ultrasound probe deployment demonstrated concentric echogenic pattern. Sampling Protocol: Transbronchial needle aspiration: 3 passes. Transbronchial forceps biopsy: 5 specimens. COMPLICATIONS: Small apical pneumothorax identified. Conservative management elected.

Indication: Staging LLL Adeno.
EBUS: 4R(10mm)+, 7(19mm)+, 10L(8mm)-.
Event: Over-sedation post-op.
Action: Flumazenil 0.2mg IV.
Result: Aroused, stable. D/C after 3hr.

PROCEDURE NOTE: Ms. Garcia underwent EBUS-TBNA for staging of LLL adenocarcinoma. Lymph node stations 4R and 7 were sampled and confirmed malignant (N3 disease relative to LLL primary). Station 10L was benign. In the recovery phase, the patient exhibited prolonged sedation and bradypnea. Flumazenil was administered with immediate positive effect. She was monitored for an extended period before discharge.

Code: 31653 (EBUS 3 stations).
Diagnosis: LLL Adenocarcinoma.
Nodes: 4R, 7, 10L.
Drug: Flumazenil used for reversal.
Pathology: Metastatic adenocarcinoma in 4R/7.

Resident Note
Patient: Helen Garcia
Procedure: EBUS
- Sampled 4R, 7, 10L.
- ROSE positive for cancer in 4R and 7.
- Patient too sleepy in PACU.
- Gave Flumazenil.
- Woke up fine.

helen garcia for ebus staging. gave midazolam and fentanyl. did the exam 4r and 7 were positive for cancer 10l negative. after the procedure she was really groggy breathing slow. had to give flumazenil to wake her up. she came around quick. kept her a bit longer to make sure she didnt get sleepy again.

PATIENT: HELEN GARCIA / ID: QR-8374-M / DATE OF BIRTH: 01/07/1958 INDICATION: Mediastinal staging for LLL adenocarcinoma SEDATION: Moderate sedation protocol initiated Midazolam 4mg IV (given incrementally) Fentanyl 125mcg IV total dose Target Ramsay 3-4 achieved EBUS PROCEDURE: Systematic N3->N2->N1 evaluation - Station 4R (10mm): 4 passes, PET+, ROSE positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma - Station 7 (19mm): 4 passes, PET+, ROSE positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
Staging LLL Ca.
[Anesthesia]
Moderate Sedation.
[Description]
EBUS-TBNA 4R, 7, 10L. N3 disease confirmed. Post-op sedation required reversal with Flumazenil.
[Plan]
Oncology.

Ms. Garcia underwent staging for her lung cancer. We found that the cancer had spread to the lymph nodes on the right side (4R) and the center (7), which is important for her treatment plan. After the procedure, she was very slow to wake up and her breathing was shallow, so we gave her a medication called Flumazenil to reverse the sedation. She woke up immediately and went home safely after extra monitoring.

PATIENT: HELEN GARCIA. INDICATION: Mediastinal staging. EBUS PROCEDURE: Systematic evaluation. Station 4R: 4 passes, ROSE positive. Station 7: 4 passes, ROSE positive. Station 10L: 3 passes, ROSE benign. COMPLICATION: Patient remained overly sedated. FLUMAZENIL administered. Immediate improvement in alertness. No other adverse events.

Indication: RUL mass, staging.
EBUS: 2R, 4R, 7 (All Positive). 10R Benign.
Bronch: RUL mass biopsy x6.
Result: Stage IIIB.
Comp: Mod bleeding, controlled.

OPERATIVE REPORT: Ms. Wang presented for diagnostic and staging bronchoscopy. EBUS-TBNA confirmed multi-station N2/N3 disease (Stations 2R, 4R, 7 positive). The bronchoscope was then used to visualize and biopsy a large RUL mass causing partial obstruction. Adequate tissue was obtained for molecular profiling. Hemostasis was secured with topical epinephrine.

Codes: 31653 (EBUS 4 stations), 31625 (Bronchial biopsy).
Sites: 2R, 4R, 7, 10R (EBUS); RUL (Biopsy).
Diagnosis: Lung Ca, Stage IIIB.
Note: High complexity staging and diagnosis.

Resident Note
Patient: Jennifer Wang
Procedure: EBUS + Biopsy
- EBUS: 2R, 4R, 7, 10R.
- ROSE pos in 2R, 4R, 7.
- Bronchoscopy: Biopsied RUL mass.
- Bleeding required epi.
- Plan: Chemoradiation.

jennifer wang 61 female rul mass. did ebus first. 2r 4r and 7 all cancer. 10r was ok. then looked at the rul mass it was blocking the airway a bit. took 6 biopsies and brushed it. bleeding was moderate used iced saline. confirmed stage 3b. need molecular markers.

Patient: Jennifer Wang | ID: RR-3847-P | Birth Date: 06/28/1963 Date of Service: 10/22/2024 | Time: 10:30 AM Chief Indication: RUL mass with mediastinal LAD, diagnostic + staging HPI: 61F, 35 pack-year smoker (active), presents with 3-month history of cough and right-sided chest discomfort. CT chest shows 3.2cm RUL mass with bulky mediastinal lymphadenopathy. PET-CT reveals primary lesion SUV 9.4, multiple N2 stations PET-avid (4R, 7, 2R). Procedure Performed: 1. EBUS-TBNA for staging 2. Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsy... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
RUL Mass, Staging.
[Anesthesia]
Moderate Sedation.
[Description]
EBUS-TBNA 2R, 4R, 7, 10R. Malignancy in mediastinal nodes. Endobronchial biopsy of RUL mass. Bleeding controlled.
[Plan]
Oncology.

We performed a comprehensive procedure for Ms. Wang to diagnose her lung mass and check the lymph nodes. The EBUS portion showed extensive spread to the lymph nodes (2R, 4R, and 7). We also biopsied the main tumor in the right upper lobe. This confirms advanced stage disease (IIIB). We managed some bleeding during the biopsy, and she recovered well.

Patient: Jennifer Wang. Chief Indication: RUL mass with mediastinal LAD. Procedure Performed: EBUS-TBNA for staging. Flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsy. EBUS Component: Station 2R: 4 passes, ROSE Positive. Station 4R: 5 passes, ROSE Positive. Station 7: 4 passes, ROSE Positive. Station 10R: 3 passes, ROSE benign. Bronchoscopy Component: Examination revealed mass effect. Multiple forceps biopsies acquired. Assessment: N2/N3 disease verified.

Indication: RLL 21mm nodule, bronchus sign+.
Technique: Traditional bronch (no nav). Fluoroscopy used.
Sampling: TBNA x3, TBBx x8, Brush x2.
Result: Lesion visualized. Diagnostic yield high.
Comp: Minor bleeding.

PROCEDURE NOTE: Mr. Thompson underwent diagnostic bronchoscopy for an RLL nodule. Due to a positive bronchus sign, traditional thin bronchoscopy was utilized without electromagnetic navigation. The lesion was visualized endobronchially and confirmed with radial EBUS. Transbronchial needle aspiration and forceps biopsies were performed under fluoroscopic guidance. Tolerance was excellent.

Codes: 31629 (TBNA), 31654 (rEBUS).
Note: No 31627 (Nav) charged - traditional approach used.
Biopsy: RLL nodule.
Fluoroscopy time: 3.1 min.

Resident Note
Patient: Mark Thompson
Procedure: Bronchoscopy
- RLL nodule with bronchus sign.
- Went down with thin scope.
- Saw the lesion.
- Confirmed with rEBUS.
- Needle and forceps biopsies taken.
- No navigation needed.

mark thompson rll nodule. saw a bronchus sign on ct so didnt use the superdimension. just went down there and saw the mucosal irregularity. radial ebus confirmed it was solid. took needle aspirates and forceps biopsies. simple procedure no complications. discharged home.

Patient: Mark Thompson | MRN# TK-9472 | Born: 09/03/1964 INDICATION: RLL 21mm solid nodule with clear bronchus sign on CT, PET SUV 4.8 ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation, midazolam 3mg + fentanyl 75mcg Ramsay 3 throughout, monitoring BP q5min, SpO2 continuous TECHNIQUE: Traditional bronchoscopy (no navigation system needed due to bronchus sign) Procedure: - Thin bronchoscope advanced to RLL - Bronchus sign followed to nodule location - Lesion visualized endobronchially as subtle mucosal irregularity... [Rest of text]

[Indication]
RLL Nodule 21mm.
[Anesthesia]
Moderate Sedation.
[Description]
Traditional bronchoscopy to RLL. Lesion visualized. rEBUS confirmed. TBNA and TBBx performed. No Nav used.
[Plan]
Discharge.

Mr. Thompson had a nodule in his right lower lung that had a clear airway leading to it, so we didn't need the advanced navigation system. We guided the scope directly to the spot, confirmed it with ultrasound, and took samples with a needle and forceps. He had a little bleeding that stopped on its own, and he went home shortly after.

Patient: Mark Thompson. INDICATION: RLL 21mm solid nodule. TECHNIQUE: Traditional bronchoscopy. Procedure: Thin bronchoscope advanced to RLL. Lesion visualized endobronchially. Radial EBUS probe: Solid eccentric pattern. Sampling performed: Transbronchial needle aspiration x3. Transbronchial forceps biopsy x5. Brush cytology x2. Complications: Minor self-limited hemorrhage.

Indication: Hx Breast CA, Adenopathy.
EBUS: 2R, 4R, 7.
Result: All positive for metastatic breast adenocarcinoma.
Plan: Oncology for systemic therapy.
Limit: No PET (CKD).

PROCEDURE REPORT: Ms. Lopez, with a history of breast cancer and CKD, presented for evaluation of mediastinal lymphadenopathy. EBUS-TBNA was performed on stations 2R, 4R, and 7. Rapid on-site evaluation was consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma of breast origin in all sampled stations. Sedation was titrated carefully due to renal dysfunction. The patient remained stable.

Code: 31653 (EBUS 3 stations).
Pathology: Metastatic Breast Cancer.
Stations: 2R, 4R, 7.
Comorbidities: CKD Stage 3 (modified sedation).
Adequacy: Confirmed.

Resident Note
Patient: Sandra Lopez
Procedure: EBUS
- History of breast cancer.
- Sampled 2R, 4R, 7.
- ROSE showed breast cancer cells.
- Used lower sedation dose because of kidneys.
- No issues.

Mediastinal adenopathy, hx Breast CA.
[Anesthesia]

EBUS-TBNA 2R, 4R, 7. Metastatic breast CA confirmed.

Ms. Lopez has a history of breast cancer and kidney disease. We performed an EBUS to check swollen lymph nodes in her chest. We sampled stations 2R, 4R, and 7. Unfortunately, all showed cells consistent with breast cancer returning. We used a lower dose of sedation because of her kidneys, and she tolerated the procedure very well.

Patient: Sandra Lopez. PROBLEM LIST: Mediastinal lymphadenopathy. History of breast cancer. Chronic kidney disease stage 3. OBJECTIVE: Procedure: EBUS-TBNA. Sedation: Moderate. Findings: Station 2R: sampled x3, ROSE displays metastatic adenocarcinoma. Station 4R: sampled x4, ROSE positive. Station 7: sampled x3, ROSE positive. ASSESSMENT: Metastatic breast cancer verified.
